title: Man is banned from keeping dogs for five years after he punched Staffordshire bull terrier
text:
A man has been banned from keeping dogs for five years after shocking footage emerged of him punching his pet.

The video obtained by the RSPCA shows Kieran Huelin of Bolton, Greater Manchester, hitting and shouting at his pooch Rosie on a number of occasions.

The animal charity was called to investigate after they were sent the video showing a man attacking a Staffordshire bull terrier in a property.

Footage showed Kieran Huelin of Bolton, Greater Manchester, hitting and shouting at his pooch Rosie on a number of occasions

Inspector Danni Jennings was sent to investigate at Huelin's flat in Bolton, Greater Manchester in June 14.

The RSPCA were also provided with some details of where the incident is said to have taken place.

She recognised Huelin who lived at the flat as the man in the video and the dog called Rosie was also there.

The man has been banned from keeping dogs for five years after shocking footage emerged of him punching his pet. His dog Rosie is pictured above

The court heard how Huelin signed Rosie over into RSPCA care while an investigation took place.

Inspector Jennings said: 'Dog owners should always make sure their pets are handled properly and not stressed or endangered with any aggressive or anti-social behaviour.

'Training should always be reward-based and should not include physical punishment as this may cause pain, suffering and distress.

'Rosie is a lovely and bouncy dog in real life but on this footage she is quite the opposite.'

Huelin, of, Bolton, admitted to one count under the Animal Welfare Act when he appeared before Bolton magistrates' court.

As well as the five year ban, he was also given a 12-month community order - including an alcohol treatment order - and was ordered to pay £800 costs and an £85 victim surcharge.
